Description: Egyptian terracotta vessel in the form of a bunch of grapes with the head of a woman. Spout above woman's head has broken away. Pierced lug at top of back to hang vessel. Mould-made and hollow. White (gypsum) coating with traces of paint. Dark red-brown Nile silt fabric with abundant fine gold mica, quartz, organics and white inclusions.
Findspot: Excavated/Findspot: Hellenion (Naukratis), Site 9 (Hogarth), Site 11 (Hogarth), Site 12 (Hogarth), Site 14 (Hogarth), Site 14a (Hogarth) or Well B (Hogarth Site 35)
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by the Museum of Classical Archaeology, Cambridge. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Resembles Ptolemaic terracottas workshop fabric from Naukratis. A bunch of grapes, possibly as a fragment of flask have parallels from Egypt (Bailey 2008. no. 3337, 3783 and particularly 3784) dated 1st century BC to 1st century AD date, though similar vessels have also been dated up to the 3rd century AD (Dunand 1990: no. 1102, Roman; Bayer-Niemeier 1988: no.757, 3rd century AD). Cambridge MCA fragments NA327, NA467 and NA630 may be from the same vessel. Bayer Niemeier, E. 1988. Liebieghaus Museum Alter Plastik. Bildweke der Sammlung Kaufmann, 1. Griechisch-römische Terrakotten. Melsungen. Dunand, F. 1990. Musée du Louvre. Département des antiquités égyptiennes. Catalogue des terres cuites grécoromaines d'Egypte. Paris.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (DD.605) (Phase 1)
Gutch 1898/1899 / Excavations at Naukratis, D. The Terracottas (p. 81, no. 41)
